utterances: That officially happened yesterday.
I mean it's been underway for the last couple of months.
It was clear that it wasn't going to be him.
And so now where is he?
Well, now Judge - a Florida judge yesterday, told him he was a free man.
The state of Florida had no further claims on him.

The various prosecutors involved in the crimes he did commit, i.e. escape, which is a crime, whether you're guilty or innocent - you're not allowed to escape - they all agreed that there was no interest in the justice system, in prosecuting him for that.

So, Florida let him go, but the immigration officials immediately arrested him - rearrested him - and are holding him while they decide whether he should be deported or not, for having committed crimes while - he was legally here in the country, but he was not a citizen.
Now, are these crimes he admits to committing, or are these the crimes that his alter egos had committed?
It appears they are saying that he's responsible for the crimes that these alter egos committed, and to which he stood up in court and took the wrap.
Well, thanks a lot.
Thank you.
Jim Dwyer is a reporter with the New York Times.

Floyd Mayweather and Shane Mosley have been on a press tour to promote their upcoming prize fight on May 1st.

(Singing) I dont drink at bars.

Mr. Mayweather was friendly, intense, and about as modest as someone with 40 wins can be.
I always knew that I was going to be a great fighter someday.
I think when you go out there and say that youre going to win, that you truly believe in yourself.
When you believe in yourself a hundred percent, then that's when I think they call it arrogance and cocky.
But when youre not too sure of yourself and you come out victorious, I think people think that's when youre humble.

Your blessings come from?
God.

Charlie Cork(ph) is building his dream home, all 8,200 square feet of it.
We're standing in his future backyard, wedged between the 13th and 18th fairways of a golf course.
It's an acre-and-a-half lot, but when you stand out in the back, all the homes are built that are going to be built.
So it looks likes a 20-acre lot, and we've got 10-acres of manicured grass so we don't have to mow a blade of it.
Welcome to Scottsdale, Arizona's Troon North, a luxury community where those manicured acres of golf links stand out against the cactus-studded Sonoran Desert.
Cork's home is going to be in what he calls an old-world European style, lot's of stone work and two turrets sort of like a castle.
It will also have a wine cellar, an elevator and a separate guesthouse.
It's coming up pretty good.
We're pretty excited about it.
Cork's in the luxury homebuilding business and he's upgrading his own home.
His current 6,500 square foot mansion two doors down is on the market for $3 million.
To put this in perspective, the average home in the Phoenix area goes for about $260,000.
Cork's real estate agent, Evan Camps(ph), says in the past decade the luxury housing market here has exploded.
If you had come to me five to six years ago and said I want to find a home above $5 million, maybe I'd find five available, if that.
Today there could be 80.
Across the country in places like Las Vegas, Southern California and Phoenix, the midrange market may be in a slump but the high end is doing just fine.
In L.A.
the value of the average luxury home was up more than 3.5 percent last quarter to $2.44 million.
The luxury market is still what we call a silver lining in this kind of turbulent market.
Jim Remley is the president of the Luxury Home Council, a group of more than a thousand real estate agents specializing in luxury homes.
He says what qualifies as a luxury home varies from city to city.
But broadly, he says, it's a house worth at least twice the average sales price in a given market.
Remley says over the past few years as housing prices rose, a lot of average homebuyers were priced out.
High-end buyers were not.
The luxury home market is not dictated by what the average Joe and Jane can buy.
It's dictated by what the average high-level executive or entrepreneur can buy.
And as the stock market and the business environment in general does well, these people can afford more and more and more.
Then there's the simple fact that more Americans have more money.
According to the research firm TNS, there are now 9.3 million millionaires, a record high.
And so long as Phoenix remains a popular place to retire and prices stay lower than in New York or California, business will remain strong for Charlie Cork and his agent.
Whatever works for...
Back in Troon North, tucked between the 13th and 18th fairways, Cork says he know as he's fortunate to be able to live in such a lovely and large home.
I'm not sure what I've done to deserve that fortune.
But yes, I'm blessed.
The view from his lot is stunning.
The only drawback might be the occasional errant golf ball flying through a window.
But Cork says he's accounted for that and the very expensive glass he's installing is heavy enough to withstand any stray shots.
